90// Class to maintain directories for all database paths other than main one.
91class Directories {
92 public:
93 IOStatus SetDirectories(FileSystem* fs, const std::string& dbname,
94 const std::string& wal_dir,
95 const std::vector<DbPath>& data_paths);
96
97 FSDirectory* GetDataDir(size_t path_id) const {
98 assert(path_id < data_dirs_.size());
99 FSDirectory* ret_dir = data_dirs_[path_id].get();
100 if (ret_dir == nullptr) {
101 // Should use db_dir_
102 return db_dir_.get();
103 }
104 return ret_dir;
105 }
106
107 FSDirectory* GetWalDir() {
108 if (wal_dir_) {
109 return wal_dir_.get();
110 }
111 return db_dir_.get();
112 }
113
114 FSDirectory* GetDbDir() { return db_dir_.get(); }
115
116 IOStatus Close(const IOOptions& options, IODebugContext* dbg) {
117 // close all directories for all database paths
118 IOStatus s = IOStatus::OK();
119
120 // The default implementation for Close() in Directory/FSDirectory class
121 // "NotSupported" status, the upper level interface should be able to
122 // handle this error so that Close() does not fail after upgrading when
123 // run on FileSystems that have not implemented `Directory::Close()` or
124 // `FSDirectory::Close()` yet
125
126 if (db_dir_) {
127 IOStatus temp_s = db_dir_->Close(options, dbg);
128 if (!temp_s.ok() && !temp_s.IsNotSupported() && s.ok()) {
129 s = std::move(temp_s);
130 }
131 }
132
133 // Attempt to close everything even if one fails
134 s.PermitUncheckedError();
135
136 if (wal_dir_) {
137 IOStatus temp_s = wal_dir_->Close(options, dbg);
138 if (!temp_s.ok() && !temp_s.IsNotSupported() && s.ok()) {
139 s = std::move(temp_s);
140 }
141 }
142
143 s.PermitUncheckedError();
144
145 for (auto& data_dir_ptr : data_dirs_) {
146 if (data_dir_ptr) {
147 IOStatus temp_s = data_dir_ptr->Close(options, dbg);
148 if (!temp_s.ok() && !temp_s.IsNotSupported() && s.ok()) {
149 s = std::move(temp_s);
150 }
151 }
152 }
153
154 // Ready for caller
155 s.MustCheck();
156 return s;
157 }
158
159 private:
160 std::unique_ptr<FSDirectory> db_dir_;
161 std::vector<std::unique_ptr<FSDirectory>> data_dirs_;
162 std::unique_ptr<FSDirectory> wal_dir_;
163};

165// While DB is the public interface of RocksDB, and DBImpl is the actual
166// class implementing it. It's the entrance of the core RocksdB engine.
167// All other DB implementations, e.g. TransactionDB, BlobDB, etc, wrap a
168// DBImpl internally.
169// Other than functions implementing the DB interface, some public
170// functions are there for other internal components to call. For
171// example, TransactionDB directly calls DBImpl::WriteImpl() and
172// BlobDB directly calls DBImpl::GetImpl(). Some other functions
173// are for sub-components to call. For example, ColumnFamilyHandleImpl
174// calls DBImpl::FindObsoleteFiles().
175//
176// Since it's a very large class, the definition of the functions is
177// divided in several db_impl_*.cc files, besides db_impl.cc.
178class DBImpl : public DB {
179 public:
180 DBImpl(const DBOptions& options, const std::string& dbname,
181 const bool seq_per_batch = false, const bool batch_per_txn = true,
182 bool read_only = false);
183 // No copying allowed
184 DBImpl(const DBImpl&) = delete;
185 void operator=(const DBImpl&) = delete;
186
187 virtual ~DBImpl();
188

269 using DB::MultiGet;
270 // This MultiGet is a batched version, which may be faster than calling Get
271 // multiple times, especially if the keys have some spatial locality that
272 // enables them to be queried in the same SST files/set of files. The larger
273 // the batch size, the more scope for batching and performance improvement
274 // The values and statuses parameters are arrays with number of elements
275 // equal to keys.size(). This allows the storage for those to be alloacted
276 // by the caller on the stack for small batches
277 void MultiGet(const ReadOptions& _read_options, const size_t num_keys,
278 ColumnFamilyHandle** column_families, const Slice* keys,
279 PinnableSlice* values, std::string* timestamps,
280 Status* statuses, const bool sorted_input = false) override;
281
282 void MultiGetWithCallback(
283 const ReadOptions& _read_options, ColumnFamilyHandle* column_family,
284 ReadCallback* callback,
285 autovector<KeyContext*, MultiGetContext::MAX_BATCH_SIZE>* sorted_keys);

581 // Verify the checksums of files in db. Currently only tables are checked.
582 //

584 // reading all the live table files.

587 // in db. Otherwise, obtain the file checksums and compare
588 // with the MANIFEST. Currently, file checksums are
589 // recomputed by reading all table files.

591 // Returns: OK if there is no file whose file or block checksum mismatches.

641 struct GetImplOptions {
642 ColumnFamilyHandle* column_family = nullptr;
643 PinnableSlice* value = nullptr;
644 PinnableWideColumns* columns = nullptr;
645 std::string* timestamp = nullptr;
646 bool* value_found = nullptr;
647 ReadCallback* callback = nullptr;
648 bool* is_blob_index = nullptr;
649 // If true return value associated with key via value pointer else return
650 // all merge operands for key via merge_operands pointer
651 bool get_value = true;
652 // Pointer to an array of size
653 // get_merge_operands_options.expected_max_number_of_operands allocated by
654 // user
655 PinnableSlice* merge_operands = nullptr;
656 GetMergeOperandsOptions* get_merge_operands_options = nullptr;
657 int* number_of_operands = nullptr;
658 };
659
660 Status GetImpl(const ReadOptions& read_options,
661 ColumnFamilyHandle* column_family, const Slice& key,
662 PinnableSlice* value);
663
664 Status GetImpl(const ReadOptions& read_options,
665 ColumnFamilyHandle* column_family, const Slice& key,

672 // get_impl_options.key via get_impl_options.value

708
709 // Returns the sequence number that is guaranteed to be smaller than or equal
710 // to the sequence number of any key that could be inserted into the current
711 // memtables. It can then be assumed that any write with a larger(or equal)
712 // sequence number will be present in this memtable or a later memtable.
713 //
714 // If the earliest sequence number could not be determined,
715 // kMaxSequenceNumber will be returned.
716 //
717 // If include_history=true, will also search Memtables in MemTableList
718 // History.
719 SequenceNumber GetEarliestMemTableSequenceNumber(SuperVersion* sv,
720 bool include_history);
721
722 // For a given key, check to see if there are any records for this key
723 // in the memtables, including memtable history. If cache_only is false,
724 // SST files will also be checked.
725 //
726 // `key` should NOT have user-defined timestamp appended to user key even if
727 // timestamp is enabled.
728 //
729 // If a key is found, *found_record_for_key will be set to true and
730 // *seq will be set to the stored sequence number for the latest
731 // operation on this key or kMaxSequenceNumber if unknown. If user-defined
732 // timestamp is enabled for this column family and timestamp is not nullptr,
733 // then *timestamp will be set to the stored timestamp for the latest
734 // operation on this key.
735 // If no key is found, *found_record_for_key will be set to false.
736 //
737 // Note: If cache_only=false, it is possible for *seq to be set to 0 if
738 // the sequence number has been cleared from the record. If the caller is
739 // holding an active db snapshot, we know the missing sequence must be less
740 // than the snapshot's sequence number (sequence numbers are only cleared
741 // when there are no earlier active snapshots).
742 //
743 // If NotFound is returned and found_record_for_key is set to false, then no
744 // record for this key was found. If the caller is holding an active db
745 // snapshot, we know that no key could have existing after this snapshot
746 // (since we do not compact keys that have an earlier snapshot).
747 //
748 // Only records newer than or at `lower_bound_seq` are guaranteed to be
749 // returned. Memtables and files may not be checked if it only contains data
750 // older than `lower_bound_seq`.
751 //
752 // Returns OK or NotFound on success,
753 // other status on unexpected error.
754 // TODO(andrewkr): this API need to be aware of range deletion operations
755 Status GetLatestSequenceForKey(SuperVersion* sv, const Slice& key,
756 bool cache_only,
757 SequenceNumber lower_bound_seq,
758 SequenceNumber* seq, std::string* timestamp,
759 bool* found_record_for_key,
760 bool* is_blob_index);
761
762 Status TraceIteratorSeek(const uint32_t& cf_id, const Slice& key,
763 const Slice& lower_bound, const Slice upper_bound);
764 Status TraceIteratorSeekForPrev(const uint32_t& cf_id, const Slice& key,
765 const Slice& lower_bound,
766 const Slice upper_bound);
767
768 // Similar to GetSnapshot(), but also lets the db know that this snapshot
769 // will be used for transaction write-conflict checking. The DB can then
770 // make sure not to compact any keys that would prevent a write-conflict from
771 // being detected.
772 const Snapshot* GetSnapshotForWriteConflictBoundary();
773
774 // checks if all live files exist on file system and that their file sizes

778 // max_file_num_to_ignore allows bottom level compaction to filter out newly
779 // compacted SST files. Setting max_file_num_to_ignore to kMaxUint64 will
780 // disable the filtering
781 // If `final_output_level` is not nullptr, it is set to manual compaction's
782 // output level if returned status is OK, and it may or may not be set to
783 // manual compaction's output level if returned status is not OK.
784 Status RunManualCompaction(ColumnFamilyData* cfd, int input_level,
785 int output_level,
786 const CompactRangeOptions& compact_range_options,
787 const Slice* begin, const Slice* end,
788 bool exclusive, bool disallow_trivial_move,
789 uint64_t max_file_num_to_ignore,
790 const std::string& trim_ts,
791 int* final_output_level = nullptr);
792
793 // Return an internal iterator over the current state of the database.
794 // The keys of this iterator are internal keys (see format.h).
795 // The returned iterator should be deleted when no longer needed.
796 // If allow_unprepared_value is true, the returned iterator may defer reading
797 // the value and so will require PrepareValue() to be called before value();
798 // allow_unprepared_value = false is convenient when this optimization is not
799 // useful, e.g. when reading the whole column family.
800 //
801 // read_options.ignore_range_deletions determines whether range tombstones are
802 // processed in the returned interator internally, i.e., whether range
803 // tombstone covered keys are in this iterator's output.
804 // @param read_options Must outlive the returned iterator.
805 InternalIterator* NewInternalIterator(
806 const ReadOptions& read_options, Arena* arena, SequenceNumber sequence,
807 ColumnFamilyHandle* column_family = nullptr,
808 bool allow_unprepared_value = false);
809
810 // Note: to support DB iterator refresh, memtable range tombstones in the
811 // underlying merging iterator needs to be refreshed. If db_iter is not
812 // nullptr, db_iter->SetMemtableRangetombstoneIter() is called with the
813 // memtable range tombstone iterator used by the underlying merging iterator.
814 // This range tombstone iterator can be refreshed later by db_iter.
815 // @param read_options Must outlive the returned iterator.
816 InternalIterator* NewInternalIterator(const ReadOptions& read_options,
817 ColumnFamilyData* cfd,
818 SuperVersion* super_version,
819 Arena* arena, SequenceNumber sequence,
820 bool allow_unprepared_value,
821 ArenaWrappedDBIter* db_iter = nullptr);

951 // hollow transactions shell used for recovery.
952 // these will then be passed to TransactionDB so that
953 // locks can be reacquired before writing can resume.
954 struct RecoveredTransaction {
955 std::string name_;
956 bool unprepared_;
957
958 struct BatchInfo {
959 uint64_t log_number_;
960 // TODO(lth): For unprepared, the memory usage here can be big for
961 // unprepared transactions. This is only useful for rollbacks, and we
962 // can in theory just keep keyset for that.
963 WriteBatch* batch_;
964 // Number of sub-batches. A new sub-batch is created if txn attempts to
965 // insert a duplicate key,seq to memtable. This is currently used in
966 // WritePreparedTxn/WriteUnpreparedTxn.
967 size_t batch_cnt_;
968 };
969
970 // This maps the seq of the first key in the batch to BatchInfo, which
971 // contains WriteBatch and other information relevant to the batch.
972 //
973 // For WriteUnprepared, batches_ can have size greater than 1, but for
974 // other write policies, it must be of size 1.
975 std::map<SequenceNumber, BatchInfo> batches_;
976
977 explicit RecoveredTransaction(const uint64_t log, const std::string& name,
978 WriteBatch* batch, SequenceNumber seq,
979 size_t batch_cnt, bool unprepared)
980 : name_(name), unprepared_(unprepared) {
981 batches_[seq] = {log, batch, batch_cnt};
982 }
983
984 ~RecoveredTransaction() {
985 for (auto& it : batches_) {
986 delete it.second.batch_;
987 }
988 }
989
990 void AddBatch(SequenceNumber seq, uint64_t log_number, WriteBatch* batch,
991 size_t batch_cnt, bool unprepared) {
992 assert(batches_.count(seq) == 0);
993 batches_[seq] = {log_number, batch, batch_cnt};
994 // Prior state must be unprepared, since the prepare batch must be the
995 // last batch.
996 assert(unprepared_);
997 unprepared_ = unprepared;
998 }
999 };
1000
1001 bool allow_2pc() const { return immutable_db_options_.allow_2pc; }
1002
1003 std::unordered_map<std::string, RecoveredTransaction*>
1004 recovered_transactions() {
1005 return recovered_transactions_;
1006 }
1007
1008 RecoveredTransaction* GetRecoveredTransaction(const std::string& name) {
1009 auto it = recovered_transactions_.find(name);
1010 if (it == recovered_transactions_.end()) {
1011 return nullptr;
1012 } else {
1013 return it->second;
1014 }
1015 }
1016
1017 void InsertRecoveredTransaction(const uint64_t log, const std::string& name,
1018 WriteBatch* batch, SequenceNumber seq,
1019 size_t batch_cnt, bool unprepared_batch) {
1020 // For WriteUnpreparedTxn, InsertRecoveredTransaction is called multiple
1021 // times for every unprepared batch encountered during recovery.
1022 //
1023 // If the transaction is prepared, then the last call to
1024 // InsertRecoveredTransaction will have unprepared_batch = false.
1025 auto rtxn = recovered_transactions_.find(name);
1026 if (rtxn == recovered_transactions_.end()) {
1027 recovered_transactions_[name] = new RecoveredTransaction(
1028 log, name, batch, seq, batch_cnt, unprepared_batch);
1029 } else {
1030 rtxn->second->AddBatch(seq, log, batch, batch_cnt, unprepared_batch);
1031 }
1032 logs_with_prep_tracker_.MarkLogAsContainingPrepSection(log);
1033 }
1034
1035 void DeleteRecoveredTransaction(const std::string& name) {
1036 auto it = recovered_transactions_.find(name);
1037 assert(it != recovered_transactions_.end());
1038 auto* trx = it->second;
1039 recovered_transactions_.erase(it);
1040 for (const auto& info : trx->batches_) {
1041 logs_with_prep_tracker_.MarkLogAsHavingPrepSectionFlushed(
1042 info.second.log_number_);
1043 }
1044 delete trx;
1045 }
1046
1047 void DeleteAllRecoveredTransactions() {
1048 for (auto it = recovered_transactions_.begin();
1049 it != recovered_transactions_.end(); ++it) {
1050 delete it->second;
1051 }
1052 recovered_transactions_.clear();
1053 }

1262 // sequence numbers from [1, last] to map to [now minus
1263 // populate_historical_seconds, now].
1264 void RecordSeqnoToTimeMapping(uint64_t populate_historical_seconds);
1265
1266 // Everytime DB's seqno to time mapping changed (which already hold the db
1267 // mutex), we install a new SuperVersion in each column family with a shared
1268 // copy of the new mapping while holding the db mutex.
1269 // This is done for all column families even though the column family does not
1270 // explicitly enabled the
1271 // `preclude_last_level_data_seconds` or `preserve_internal_time_seconds`
1272 // features.
1273 // This mapping supports iterators to fulfill the
1274 // "rocksdb.iterator.write-time" iterator property for entries in memtables.
1275 //
1276 // Since this new SuperVersion doesn't involve an LSM tree shape change, we
1277 // don't schedule work after installing this SuperVersion. It returns the used
1278 // `SuperVersionContext` for clean up after release mutex.
1279 void InstallSeqnoToTimeMappingInSV(
1280 std::vector<SuperVersionContext>* sv_contexts);
1281
1282 // Interface to block and signal the DB in case of stalling writes by
1283 // WriteBufferManager. Each DBImpl object contains ptr to WBMStallInterface.
1284 // When DB needs to be blocked or signalled by WriteBufferManager,
1285 // state_ is changed accordingly.
1286 class WBMStallInterface : public StallInterface {
1287 public:
1288 enum State {
1289 BLOCKED = 0,
1290 RUNNING,
1291 };
1292
1293 WBMStallInterface() : state_cv_(&state_mutex_) {
1294 MutexLock lock(&state_mutex_);
1295 state_ = State::RUNNING;
1296 }
1297
1298 void SetState(State state) {
1299 MutexLock lock(&state_mutex_);
1300 state_ = state;
1301 }
1302
1303 // Change the state_ to State::BLOCKED and wait until its state is
1304 // changed by WriteBufferManager. When stall is cleared, Signal() is
1305 // called to change the state and unblock the DB.
1306 void Block() override {
1307 MutexLock lock(&state_mutex_);
1308 while (state_ == State::BLOCKED) {
1309 TEST_SYNC_POINT("WBMStallInterface::BlockDB");
1310 state_cv_.Wait();
1311 }
1312 }
1313
1314 // Called from WriteBufferManager. This function changes the state_
1315 // to State::RUNNING indicating the stall is cleared and DB can proceed.
1316 void Signal() override {
1317 {
1318 MutexLock lock(&state_mutex_);
1319 state_ = State::RUNNING;
1320 }
1321 state_cv_.Signal();
1322 }
1323
1324 private:
1325 // Conditional variable and mutex to block and
1326 // signal the DB during stalling process.
1327 port::Mutex state_mutex_;
1328 port::CondVar state_cv_;
1329 // state represting whether DB is running or blocked because of stall by
1330 // WriteBufferManager.
1331 State state_;
1332 };

1425 // RecoveryContext struct stores the context about version edits along
1426 // with corresponding column_family_data and column_family_options.
1427 class RecoveryContext {
1428 public:
1429 ~RecoveryContext() {
1430 for (auto& edit_list : edit_lists_) {
1431 for (auto* edit : edit_list) {
1432 delete edit;
1433 }
1434 }
1435 }
1436
1437 void UpdateVersionEdits(ColumnFamilyData* cfd, const VersionEdit& edit) {
1438 assert(cfd != nullptr);
1439 if (map_.find(cfd->GetID()) == map_.end()) {
1440 uint32_t size = static_cast<uint32_t>(map_.size());
1441 map_.emplace(cfd->GetID(), size);
1442 cfds_.emplace_back(cfd);
1443 mutable_cf_opts_.emplace_back(cfd->GetLatestMutableCFOptions());
1444 edit_lists_.emplace_back(autovector<VersionEdit*>());
1445 }
1446 uint32_t i = map_[cfd->GetID()];
1447 edit_lists_[i].emplace_back(new VersionEdit(edit));
1448 }
1449
1450 std::unordered_map<uint32_t, uint32_t> map_; // cf_id to index;
1451 autovector<ColumnFamilyData*> cfds_;
1452 autovector<const MutableCFOptions*> mutable_cf_opts_;
1453 autovector<autovector<VersionEdit*>> edit_lists_;
1454 // All existing data files (SST files and Blob files) found during DB::Open.
1455 std::vector<std::string> existing_data_files_;
1456 bool is_new_db_ = false;
1457 };

1512 // For CFs that has updates in `wbwi`, their memtable will be switched,
1513 // and `wbwi` will be added as the latest immutable memtable.
1514 //
1515 // REQUIRES: this thread is currently at the front of the main writer queue.
1516 // @param prep_log refers to the WAL that contains prepare record
1517 // for the transaction based on wbwi.
1518 // @param assigned_seqno Sequence numbers for the ingested memtable.
1519 // @param last_seqno the value of versions_->LastSequence() after the write
1520 // ingests `wbwi` is done.
1521 // @param memtable_updated Whether the same write that ingests wbwi has
1522 // updated memtable. This is useful for determining whether to set bg
1523 // error when IngestWBWI fails.
1524 Status IngestWBWI(std::shared_ptr<WriteBatchWithIndex> wbwi,
1525 const WBWIMemTable::SeqnoRange& assigned_seqno,
1526 uint64_t min_prep_log, SequenceNumber last_seqno,
1527 bool memtable_updated, bool ignore_missing_cf);
1528
1529 // If disable_memtable is set the application logic must guarantee that the
1530 // batch will still be skipped from memtable during the recovery. An excption
1531 // to this is seq_per_batch_ mode, in which since each batch already takes one
1532 // seq, it is ok for the batch to write to memtable during recovery as long as
1533 // it only takes one sequence number: i.e., no duplicate keys.
1534 // In WriteCommitted it is guarnateed since disable_memtable is used for
1535 // prepare batch which will be written to memtable later during the commit,
1536 // and in WritePrepared it is guaranteed since it will be used only for WAL
1537 // markers which will never be written to memtable. If the commit marker is
1538 // accompanied with CommitTimeWriteBatch that is not written to memtable as
1539 // long as it has no duplicate keys, it does not violate the one-seq-per-batch
1540 // policy.
1541 // batch_cnt is expected to be non-zero in seq_per_batch mode and
1542 // indicates the number of sub-patches. A sub-patch is a subset of the write
1543 // batch that does not have duplicate keys.
1544 // `callback` is called before WAL write.
1545 // See more in comment above WriteCallback::Callback().
1546 // pre_release_callback is called after WAL write and before memtable write.
1547 // See more in comment above PreReleaseCallback::Callback().
1548 // post_memtable_callback is called after memtable write but before publishing
1549 // the sequence number to readers.
1550 //
1551 // The main write queue. This is the only write queue that updates
1552 // LastSequence. When using one write queue, the same sequence also indicates
1553 // the last published sequence.
1554 Status WriteImpl(const WriteOptions& options, WriteBatch* updates,
1555 WriteCallback* callback = nullptr,
1556 UserWriteCallback* user_write_cb = nullptr,
1557 uint64_t* log_used = nullptr, uint64_t log_ref = 0,
1558 bool disable_memtable = false, uint64_t* seq_used = nullptr,
1559 size_t batch_cnt = 0,
1560 PreReleaseCallback* pre_release_callback = nullptr,
1561 PostMemTableCallback* post_memtable_callback = nullptr,
1562 std::shared_ptr<WriteBatchWithIndex> wbwi = nullptr,
1563 uint64_t min_prep_log = 0);
1564
1565 Status PipelinedWriteImpl(const WriteOptions& options, WriteBatch* updates,
1566 WriteCallback* callback = nullptr,
1567 UserWriteCallback* user_write_cb = nullptr,
1568 uint64_t* log_used = nullptr, uint64_t log_ref = 0,
1569 bool disable_memtable = false,
1570 uint64_t* seq_used = nullptr);
1571
1572 // Write only to memtables without joining any write queue
1573 Status UnorderedWriteMemtable(const WriteOptions& write_options,
1574 WriteBatch* my_batch, WriteCallback* callback,
1575 uint64_t log_ref, SequenceNumber seq,
1576 const size_t sub_batch_cnt);
1577
1578 // Whether the batch requires to be assigned with an order
1579 enum AssignOrder : bool { kDontAssignOrder, kDoAssignOrder };
1580 // Whether it requires publishing last sequence or not
1581 enum PublishLastSeq : bool { kDontPublishLastSeq, kDoPublishLastSeq };
1582
1583 // Join the write_thread to write the batch only to the WAL. It is the
1584 // responsibility of the caller to also write the write batch to the memtable
1585 // if it required.
1586 //
1587 // sub_batch_cnt is expected to be non-zero when assign_order = kDoAssignOrder
1588 // indicating the number of sub-batches in my_batch. A sub-patch is a subset
1589 // of the write batch that does not have duplicate keys. When seq_per_batch is
1590 // not set, each key is a separate sub_batch. Otherwise each duplicate key
1591 // marks start of a new sub-batch.
1592 Status WriteImplWALOnly(
1593 WriteThread* write_thread, const WriteOptions& options,
1594 WriteBatch* updates, WriteCallback* callback,
1595 UserWriteCallback* user_write_cb, uint64_t* log_used,
1596 const uint64_t log_ref, uint64_t* seq_used, const size_t sub_batch_cnt,
1597 PreReleaseCallback* pre_release_callback, const AssignOrder assign_order,
1598 const PublishLastSeq publish_last_seq, const bool disable_memtable);

1634 // REQUIRES: db mutex held when calling this function, but the db mutex can
1635 // be released and re-acquired. Db mutex will be held when the function
1636 // returns.
1637 // It stores all existing data files (SST and Blob) in RecoveryContext. In
1638 // the meantime, we find out the largest file number present in the paths, and
1639 // bump up the version set's next_file_number_ to be 1 + largest_file_number.
1640 // recovery_ctx stores the context about version edits. All those edits are
1641 // persisted to new Manifest after successfully syncing the new WAL.
1642 Status MaybeUpdateNextFileNumber(RecoveryContext* recovery_ctx);
1643
1644 // Track existing data files, including both referenced and unreferenced SST
1645 // and Blob files in SstFileManager. This is only called during DB::Open and
1646 // it's called before any file deletion start so that their deletion can be
1647 // properly rate limited.
1648 // Files may not be referenced in the MANIFEST because (e.g.
1649 // 1. It's best effort recovery;
1650 // 2. The VersionEdits referencing the SST files are appended to
1651 // RecoveryContext, DB crashes when syncing the MANIFEST, the VersionEdits are
1652 // still not synced to MANIFEST during recovery.)
1653 //
1654 // If the file is referenced in Manifest (typically that's the
1655 // vast majority of all files), since it already has the file size
1656 // on record, we don't need to query the file system. Otherwise, we query the
1657 // file system for the size of an unreferenced file.
1658 // REQUIRES: mutex unlocked
1659 void TrackExistingDataFiles(
1660 const std::vector<std::string>& existing_data_files);
1661
1662 // Untrack data files in sst manager. This is only called during DB::Close on
1663 // an unowned SstFileManager, to return it to a consistent state.
1664 // REQUIRES: mutex unlocked
1665 void UntrackDataFiles();

1675 // Check that the read timestamp `ts` is at or above the `full_history_ts_low`
1676 // timestamp in a `SuperVersion`. It's necessary to do this check after
1677 // grabbing the SuperVersion. If the check passed, the referenced SuperVersion
1678 // this read holds on to can ensure the read won't be affected if
1679 // `full_history_ts_low` is increased concurrently, and this achieves that
1680 // without explicitly locking by piggybacking the SuperVersion.

1756 struct LogFileNumberSize {
1757 explicit LogFileNumberSize(uint64_t _number) : number(_number) {}
1758 LogFileNumberSize() {}
1759 void AddSize(uint64_t new_size) { size += new_size; }
1760 uint64_t number;
1761 uint64_t size = 0;
1762 bool getting_flushed = false;
1763 };
1764
1765 struct LogWriterNumber {
1766 // pass ownership of _writer
1767 LogWriterNumber(uint64_t _number, log::Writer* _writer)
1768 : number(_number), writer(_writer) {}
1769
1770 log::Writer* ReleaseWriter() {
1771 auto* w = writer;
1772 writer = nullptr;
1773 return w;
1774 }
1775 Status ClearWriter() {
1776 Status s;
1777 if (writer->file()) {
1778 // TODO: plumb Env::IOActivity, Env::IOPriority
1779 s = writer->WriteBuffer(WriteOptions());
1780 }
1781 delete writer;
1782 writer = nullptr;
1783 return s;
1784 }
1785
1786 bool IsSyncing() { return getting_synced; }
1787
1788 uint64_t GetPreSyncSize() {
1789 assert(getting_synced);
1790 return pre_sync_size;
1791 }
1792
1793 void PrepareForSync() {
1794 assert(!getting_synced);
1795 // Ensure the head of logs_ is marked as getting_synced if any is.
1796 getting_synced = true;
1797 // If last sync failed on a later WAL, this could be a fully synced
1798 // and closed WAL that just needs to be recorded as synced in the
1799 // manifest.
1800 if (writer->file()) {
1801 // Size is expected to be monotonically increasing.
1802 assert(writer->file()->GetFlushedSize() >= pre_sync_size);
1803 pre_sync_size = writer->file()->GetFlushedSize();
1804 }
1805 }
1806
1807 void FinishSync() {
1808 assert(getting_synced);
1809 getting_synced = false;
1810 }
1811
1812 uint64_t number;
1813 // Visual Studio doesn't support deque's member to be noncopyable because
1814 // of a std::unique_ptr as a member.
1815 log::Writer* writer; // own
1816
1817 private:
1818 // true for some prefix of logs_
1819 bool getting_synced = false;
1820 // The size of the file before the sync happens. This amount is guaranteed
1821 // to be persisted even if appends happen during sync so it can be used for
1822 // tracking the synced size in MANIFEST.
1823 uint64_t pre_sync_size = 0;
1824 };

1829 bool need_log_sync = false;
1830 bool need_log_dir_sync = false;
1831 log::Writer* writer = nullptr;
1832 LogFileNumberSize* log_file_number_size = nullptr;
1833 };

1852 max_memtable_id_(0),
1853 superversion_context_(nullptr),
1854 flush_reason_(FlushReason::kOthers) {}
1855 BGFlushArg(ColumnFamilyData* cfd, uint64_t max_memtable_id,
1856 SuperVersionContext* superversion_context,
1857 FlushReason flush_reason)
1858 : cfd_(cfd),
1859 max_memtable_id_(max_memtable_id),
1860 superversion_context_(superversion_context),
1861 flush_reason_(flush_reason) {}
1862
1863 // Column family to flush.
1864 ColumnFamilyData* cfd_;
1865 // Maximum ID of memtable to flush. In this column family, memtables with
1866 // IDs smaller than this value must be flushed before this flush completes.
1867 uint64_t max_memtable_id_;
1868 // Pointer to a SuperVersionContext object. After flush completes, RocksDB
1869 // installs a new superversion for the column family. This operation
1870 // requires a SuperVersionContext object (currently embedded in JobContext).
1871 SuperVersionContext* superversion_context_;
1872 FlushReason flush_reason_;
1873 };

1877 DBImpl* db_;
1878
1879 Env::Priority thread_pri_;
1880 };

1882 // Information for a manual compaction
1883 struct ManualCompactionState {
1884 ManualCompactionState(ColumnFamilyData* _cfd, int _input_level,
1885 int _output_level, uint32_t _output_path_id,
1886 bool _exclusive, bool _disallow_trivial_move,
1887 std::atomic<bool>* _canceled)
1888 : cfd(_cfd),
1889 input_level(_input_level),
1890 output_level(_output_level),
1891 output_path_id(_output_path_id),
1892 exclusive(_exclusive),
1893 disallow_trivial_move(_disallow_trivial_move),
1894 canceled(_canceled ? *_canceled : canceled_internal_storage) {}
1895 // When _canceled is not provided by ther user, we assign the reference of
1896 // canceled_internal_storage to it to consolidate canceled and
1897 // manual_compaction_paused since DisableManualCompaction() might be
1898 // called
1899
1900 ColumnFamilyData* cfd;
1901 int input_level;
1902 int output_level;
1903 uint32_t output_path_id;
1904 Status status;
1905 bool done = false;
1906 bool in_progress = false; // compaction request being processed?
1907 bool incomplete = false; // only part of requested range compacted
1908 bool exclusive; // current behavior of only one manual
1909 bool disallow_trivial_move; // Force actual compaction to run
1910 const InternalKey* begin = nullptr; // nullptr means beginning of key range
1911 const InternalKey* end = nullptr; // nullptr means end of key range
1912 InternalKey* manual_end = nullptr; // how far we are compacting
1913 InternalKey tmp_storage; // Used to keep track of compaction progress
1914 InternalKey tmp_storage1; // Used to keep track of compaction progress
1915
1916 // When the user provides a canceled pointer in CompactRangeOptions, the
1917 // above varaibe is the reference of the user-provided
1918 // `canceled`, otherwise, it is the reference of canceled_internal_storage
1919 std::atomic<bool> canceled_internal_storage = false;
1920 std::atomic<bool>& canceled; // Compaction canceled pointer reference
1921 };
1922 struct PrepickedCompaction {
1923 // background compaction takes ownership of `compaction`.
1924 Compaction* compaction;
1925 // caller retains ownership of `manual_compaction_state` as it is reused
1926 // across background compactions.
1927 ManualCompactionState* manual_compaction_state; // nullptr if non-manual
1928 // task limiter token is requested during compaction picking.
1929 std::unique_ptr<TaskLimiterToken> task_token;

2150 inline void WaitForPendingWrites() {
2151 mutex_.AssertHeld();
2152 TEST_SYNC_POINT("DBImpl::WaitForPendingWrites:BeforeBlock");
2153 // In case of pipelined write is enabled, wait for all pending memtable
2154 // writers.
2155 if (immutable_db_options_.enable_pipelined_write) {
2156 // Memtable writers may call DB::Get in case max_successive_merges > 0,
2157 // which may lock mutex. Unlocking mutex here to avoid deadlock.
2158 mutex_.Unlock();
2159 write_thread_.WaitForMemTableWriters();
2160 mutex_.Lock();
2161 }
2162
2163 if (immutable_db_options_.unordered_write) {
2164 // Wait for the ones who already wrote to the WAL to finish their
2165 // memtable write.
2166 if (pending_memtable_writes_.load() != 0) {
2167 // XXX: suspicious wait while holding DB mutex?
2168 std::unique_lock<std::mutex> guard(switch_mutex_);
2169 switch_cv_.wait(guard,
2170 [&] { return pending_memtable_writes_.load() == 0; });
2171 }
2172 } else {
2173 // (Writes are finished before the next write group starts.)
2174 }
2175
2176 // Wait for any LockWAL to clear
2177 while (lock_wal_count_ > 0) {
2178 bg_cv_.Wait();
2179 }
2180 }

2182 // TaskType is used to identify tasks in thread-pool, currently only
2183 // differentiate manual compaction, which could be unscheduled from the
2184 // thread-pool.
2185 enum class TaskType : uint8_t {
2186 kDefault = 0,
2187 kManualCompaction = 1,
2188 kCount = 2,
2189 };
2190
2191 // Task tag is used to identity tasks in thread-pool, which is
2192 // dbImpl obj address + type
2193 inline void* GetTaskTag(TaskType type) {
2194 return GetTaskTag(static_cast<uint8_t>(type));
2195 }
2196
2197 inline void* GetTaskTag(uint8_t type) {
2198 return static_cast<uint8_t*>(static_cast<void*>(this)) + type;
2199 }

2265 struct FlushRequest {
2266 FlushReason flush_reason;
2267 // A map from column family to flush to largest memtable id to persist for
2268 // each column family. Once all the memtables whose IDs are smaller than or
2269 // equal to this per-column-family specified value, this flush request is
2270 // considered to have completed its work of flushing this column family.
2271 // After completing the work for all column families in this request, this
2272 // flush is considered complete.
2273 std::unordered_map<ColumnFamilyData*, uint64_t>
2274 cfd_to_max_mem_id_to_persist;
2275
2276#ifndef NDEBUG
2277 int reschedule_count = 1;
2278#endif /* !NDEBUG */
2279 };
2280
2281 // In case of atomic flush, generates a `FlushRequest` for the latest atomic
2282 // cuts for these `cfds`. Atomic cuts are recorded in
2283 // `AssignAtomicFlushSeq()`. For each entry in `cfds`, all CFDs sharing the
2284 // same latest atomic cut must also be present.
2285 //
2286 // REQUIRES: mutex held
2287 void GenerateFlushRequest(const autovector<ColumnFamilyData*>& cfds,
2288 FlushReason flush_reason, FlushRequest* req);
2289
2290 // Below functions are for executing flush, compaction in the background. A
2291 // dequeue is the communication channel between threads that asks for the work
2292 // to be done and the available threads in the thread pool that pick it up to
2293 // execute it. We use these terminologies to describe the state of the work
2294 // and its transitions:
2295 // 1) It becomes pending once it's successfully enqueued into the
2296 // corresponding dequeue, a work in this state is also called unscheduled.
2297 // Counter `unscheduled_*_` counts work in this state.
2298 // 2) When `MaybeScheduleFlushOrCompaction` schedule a thread to run `BGWork*`
2299 // for the work, it becomes scheduled
2300 // Counter `bg_*_scheduled_` counts work in this state.
2301 // 3) Once the thread start to execute `BGWork*`, the work is popped from the
2302 // dequeue, it is now in running state
2303 // Counter `num_running_*_` counts work in this state.
2304 // 4) Eventually, the work is finished. We don't need to specifically track
2305 // finished work.
2306
2307 // Returns true if `req` is successfully enqueued.
2308 bool EnqueuePendingFlush(const FlushRequest& req);
2309
2310 void EnqueuePendingCompaction(ColumnFamilyData* cfd);
2311 void SchedulePendingPurge(std::string fname, std::string dir_to_sync,
2312 FileType type, uint64_t number, int job_id);
2313 static void BGWorkCompaction(void* arg);
2314 // Runs a pre-chosen universal compaction involving bottom level in a
2315 // separate, bottom-pri thread pool.
2316 static void BGWorkBottomCompaction(void* arg);
2317 static void BGWorkFlush(void* arg);
2318 static void BGWorkPurge(void* arg);
2319 static void UnscheduleCompactionCallback(void* arg);
2320 static void UnscheduleFlushCallback(void* arg);
2321 void BackgroundCallCompaction(PrepickedCompaction* prepicked_compaction,
2322 Env::Priority thread_pri);
2323 void BackgroundCallFlush(Env::Priority thread_pri);
2324 void BackgroundCallPurge();
2325 Status BackgroundCompaction(bool* madeProgress, JobContext* job_context,
2326 LogBuffer* log_buffer,

2328 Env::Priority thread_pri);

2503 // list.

2534 // A common function to obtain a consistent snapshot, which can be implicit
2535 // if the user doesn't specify a snapshot in read_options, across
2536 // multiple column families. It will attempt to get an implicit
2537 // snapshot without acquiring the db_mutes, but will give up after a few
2538 // tries and acquire the mutex if a memtable flush happens. The template
2539 // allows both the batched and non-batched MultiGet to call this with
2540 // either an std::unordered_map or autovector of column families.
2541 //
2542 // If callback is non-null, the callback is refreshed with the snapshot
2543 // sequence number
2544 //
2545 // `extra_sv_ref` is used to indicate whether thread-local SuperVersion
2546 // should be obtained with an extra ref (by GetReferencedSuperVersion()) or
2547 // not (by GetAndRefSuperVersion()). For instance, point lookup like MultiGet
2548 // does not require SuperVersion to be re-acquired throughout the entire
2549 // invocation (no need extra ref), while MultiCfIterators may need the
2550 // SuperVersion to be updated during Refresh() (requires extra ref).
2551 //
2552 // `sv_from_thread_local` being set to false indicates that the SuperVersion
2553 // obtained from the ColumnFamilyData, whereas true indicates they are thread
2554 // local.
2555 //
2556 // A non-OK status will be returned if for a column family that enables
2557 // user-defined timestamp feature, the specified `ReadOptions.timestamp`
2558 // attemps to read collapsed history.
2559 template <class T, typename IterDerefFuncType>
2560 Status MultiCFSnapshot(const ReadOptions& read_options,
2561 ReadCallback* callback,
2562 IterDerefFuncType iter_deref_func, T* cf_list,
2563 bool extra_sv_ref, SequenceNumber* snapshot,
2564 bool* sv_from_thread_local);
2565
2566 // The actual implementation of the batching MultiGet. The caller is expected
2567 // to have acquired the SuperVersion and pass in a snapshot sequence number
2568 // in order to construct the LookupKeys. The start_key and num_keys specify
2569 // the range of keys in the sorted_keys vector for a single column family.
2570 Status MultiGetImpl(
2571 const ReadOptions& read_options, size_t start_key, size_t num_keys,
2572 autovector<KeyContext*, MultiGetContext::MAX_BATCH_SIZE>* sorted_keys,
2573 SuperVersion* sv, SequenceNumber snap_seqnum, ReadCallback* callback);
2574
2575 void MultiGetWithCallbackImpl(
2576 const ReadOptions& read_options, ColumnFamilyHandle* column_family,
2577 ReadCallback* callback,
2578 autovector<KeyContext*, MultiGetContext::MAX_BATCH_SIZE>* sorted_keys);

2597 // Guards changes to DB and CF options to ensure consistency between
2598 // * In-memory options objects
2599 // * Settings in effect
2600 // * Options file contents
2601 // while allowing the DB mutex to be released during slow operations like
2602 // persisting options file or modifying global periodic task timer.
2603 // Always acquired *before* DB mutex when this one is applicable.
2604 InstrumentedMutex options_mutex_;
2605
2606 // Guards reads and writes to in-memory stats_history_.
2607 InstrumentedMutex stats_history_mutex_;
2608
2609 // In addition to mutex_, log_write_mutex_ protects writes to logs_ and
2610 // logfile_number_. With two_write_queues it also protects alive_log_files_,
2611 // and log_empty_. Refer to the definition of each variable below for more
2612 // details.
2613 // Note: to avoid deadlock, if needed to acquire both log_write_mutex_ and
2614 // mutex_, the order should be first mutex_ and then log_write_mutex_.
2615 InstrumentedMutex log_write_mutex_;
2616
2617 // If zero, manual compactions are allowed to proceed. If non-zero, manual
2618 // compactions may still be running, but will quickly fail with
2619 // `Status::Incomplete`. The value indicates how many threads have paused
2620 // manual compactions. It is accessed in read mode outside the DB mutex in
2621 // compaction code paths.
2622 std::atomic<int> manual_compaction_paused_;
2623
2624 // This condition variable is signaled on these conditions:
2625 // * whenever bg_compaction_scheduled_ goes down to 0
2626 // * if AnyManualCompaction, whenever a compaction finishes, even if it hasn't
2627 // made any progress
2628 // * whenever a compaction made any progress
2629 // * whenever bg_flush_scheduled_ or bg_purge_scheduled_ value decreases
2630 // (i.e. whenever a flush is done, even if it didn't make any progress)
2631 // * whenever there is an error in background purge, flush or compaction
2632 // * whenever num_running_ingest_file_ goes to 0.
2633 // * whenever pending_purge_obsolete_files_ goes to 0.
2634 // * whenever disable_delete_obsolete_files_ goes to 0.
2635 // * whenever SetOptions successfully updates options.
2636 // * whenever a column family is dropped.
2637 InstrumentedCondVar bg_cv_;
2638 // Writes are protected by locking both mutex_ and log_write_mutex_, and reads
2639 // must be under either mutex_ or log_write_mutex_. Since after ::Open,
2640 // logfile_number_ is currently updated only in write_thread_, it can be read
2641 // from the same write_thread_ without any locks.
2642 uint64_t logfile_number_;
2643 // Log files that we can recycle. Must be protected by db mutex_.
2644 std::deque<uint64_t> log_recycle_files_;
2645 // The minimum log file number taht can be recycled, if log recycling is
2646 // enabled. This is used to ensure that log files created by previous
2647 // instances of the database are not recycled, as we cannot be sure they
2648 // were created in the recyclable format.
2649 uint64_t min_log_number_to_recycle_;
2650 // Protected by log_write_mutex_.
2651 bool log_dir_synced_;
2652 // Without two_write_queues, read and writes to log_empty_ are protected by
2653 // mutex_. Since it is currently updated/read only in write_thread_, it can be
2654 // accessed from the same write_thread_ without any locks. With
2655 // two_write_queues writes, where it can be updated in different threads,
2656 // read and writes are protected by log_write_mutex_ instead. This is to avoid
2657 // expensive mutex_ lock during WAL write, which update log_empty_.
2658 bool log_empty_;
2659
2660 ColumnFamilyHandleImpl* persist_stats_cf_handle_;
2661
2662 bool persistent_stats_cfd_exists_ = true;
2663
2664 // The current WAL file and those that have not been found obsolete from
2665 // memtable flushes. A WAL not on this list might still be pending writer
2666 // flush and/or sync and close and might still be in logs_. alive_log_files_
2667 // is protected by mutex_ and log_write_mutex_ with details as follows:
2668 // 1. read by FindObsoleteFiles() which can be called in either application
2669 // thread or RocksDB bg threads, both mutex_ and log_write_mutex_ are
2670 // held.
2671 // 2. pop_front() by FindObsoleteFiles(), both mutex_ and log_write_mutex_
2672 // are held.
2673 // 3. push_back() by DBImpl::Open() and DBImpl::RestoreAliveLogFiles()
2674 // (actually called by Open()), only mutex_ is held because at this point,
2675 // the DB::Open() call has not returned success to application, and the
2676 // only other thread(s) that can conflict are bg threads calling
2677 // FindObsoleteFiles() which ensure that both mutex_ and log_write_mutex_
2678 // are held when accessing alive_log_files_.
2679 // 4. read by DBImpl::Open() is protected by mutex_.
2680 // 5. push_back() by SwitchMemtable(). Both mutex_ and log_write_mutex_ are
2681 // held. This is done by the write group leader. Note that in the case of
2682 // two-write-queues, another WAL-only write thread can be writing to the
2683 // WAL concurrently. See 9.
2684 // 6. read by SwitchWAL() with both mutex_ and log_write_mutex_ held. This is
2685 // done by write group leader.
2686 // 7. read by ConcurrentWriteToWAL() by the write group leader in the case of
2687 // two-write-queues. Only log_write_mutex_ is held to protect concurrent
2688 // pop_front() by FindObsoleteFiles().
2689 // 8. read by PreprocessWrite() by the write group leader. log_write_mutex_
2690 // is held to protect the data structure from concurrent pop_front() by
2691 // FindObsoleteFiles().
2692 // 9. read by ConcurrentWriteToWAL() by a WAL-only write thread in the case
2693 // of two-write-queues. Only log_write_mutex_ is held. This suffices to
2694 // protect the data structure from concurrent push_back() by current
2695 // write group leader as well as pop_front() by FindObsoleteFiles().
2696 std::deque<LogFileNumberSize> alive_log_files_;
2697
2698 // Log files that aren't fully synced, and the current log file.
2699 // Synchronization:
2700 // 1. read by FindObsoleteFiles() which can be called either in application
2701 // thread or RocksDB bg threads. log_write_mutex_ is always held, while
2702 // some reads are performed without mutex_.
2703 // 2. pop_front() by FindObsoleteFiles() with only log_write_mutex_ held.
2704 // 3. read by DBImpl::Open() with both mutex_ and log_write_mutex_.
2705 // 4. emplace_back() by DBImpl::Open() with both mutex_ and log_write_mutex.
2706 // Note that at this point, DB::Open() has not returned success to
2707 // application, thus the only other thread(s) that can conflict are bg
2708 // threads calling FindObsoleteFiles(). See 1.
2709 // 5. iteration and clear() from CloseHelper() always hold log_write_mutex
2710 // and mutex_.
2711 // 6. back() called by APIs FlushWAL() and LockWAL() are protected by only
2712 // log_write_mutex_. These two can be called by application threads after
2713 // DB::Open() returns success to applications.
2714 // 7. read by SyncWAL(), another API, protected by only log_write_mutex_.
2715 // 8. read by MarkLogsNotSynced() and MarkLogsSynced() are protected by
2716 // log_write_mutex_.
2717 // 9. erase() by MarkLogsSynced() protected by log_write_mutex_.
2718 // 10. read by SyncClosedWals() protected by only log_write_mutex_. This can
2719 // happen in bg flush threads after DB::Open() returns success to
2720 // applications.
2721 // 11. reads, e.g. front(), iteration, and back() called by PreprocessWrite()
2722 // holds only the log_write_mutex_. This is done by the write group
2723 // leader. A bg thread calling FindObsoleteFiles() or MarkLogsSynced()
2724 // can happen concurrently. This is fine because log_write_mutex_ is used
2725 // by all parties. See 2, 5, 9.
2726 // 12. reads, empty(), back() called by SwitchMemtable() hold both mutex_ and
2727 // log_write_mutex_. This happens in the write group leader.
2728 // 13. emplace_back() by SwitchMemtable() hold both mutex_ and
2729 // log_write_mutex_. This happens in the write group leader. Can conflict
2730 // with bg threads calling FindObsoleteFiles(), MarkLogsSynced(),
2731 // SyncClosedWals(), etc. as well as application threads calling
2732 // FlushWAL(), SyncWAL(), LockWAL(). This is fine because all parties
2733 // require at least log_write_mutex_.
2734 // 14. iteration called in WriteToWAL(write_group) protected by
2735 // log_write_mutex_. This is done by write group leader when
2736 // two-write-queues is disabled and write needs to sync logs.
2737 // 15. back() called in ConcurrentWriteToWAL() protected by log_write_mutex_.
2738 // This can be done by the write group leader if two-write-queues is
2739 // enabled. It can also be done by another WAL-only write thread.
2740 //
2741 // Other observations:
2742 // - back() and items with getting_synced=true are not popped,
2743 // - The same thread that sets getting_synced=true will reset it.
2744 // - it follows that the object referred by back() can be safely read from
2745 // the write_thread_ without using mutex. Note that calling back() without
2746 // mutex may be unsafe because different implementations of deque::back() may
2747 // access other member variables of deque, causing undefined behaviors.
2748 // Generally, do not access stl containers without proper synchronization.
2749 // - it follows that the items with getting_synced=true can be safely read
2750 // from the same thread that has set getting_synced=true
2751 std::deque<LogWriterNumber> logs_;
2752
2753 // Signaled when getting_synced becomes false for some of the logs_.
2754 InstrumentedCondVar log_sync_cv_;
2755 // This is the app-level state that is written to the WAL but will be used
2756 // only during recovery. Using this feature enables not writing the state to
2757 // memtable on normal writes and hence improving the throughput. Each new
2758 // write of the state will replace the previous state entirely even if the
2759 // keys in the two consecutive states do not overlap.
2760 // It is protected by log_write_mutex_ when two_write_queues_ is enabled.
2761 // Otherwise only the heaad of write_thread_ can access it.
2762 WriteBatch cached_recoverable_state_;
2763 std::atomic<bool> cached_recoverable_state_empty_ = {true};
2764 std::atomic<uint64_t> total_log_size_;
2765
2766 // If this is non-empty, we need to delete these log files in background
2767 // threads. Protected by log_write_mutex_.
2768 autovector<log::Writer*> logs_to_free_;

2804 // For each background job, pending_outputs_ keeps the current file number at
2805 // the time that background job started.
2806 // FindObsoleteFiles()/PurgeObsoleteFiles() never deletes any file that has
2807 // number bigger than any of the file number in pending_outputs_. Since file
2808 // numbers grow monotonically, this also means that pending_outputs_ is always
2809 // sorted. After a background job is done executing, its file number is
2810 // deleted from pending_outputs_, which allows PurgeObsoleteFiles() to clean
2811 // it up.
2812 // State is protected with db mutex.
2813 std::list<uint64_t> pending_outputs_;
2814
2815 // Similar to pending_outputs_, FindObsoleteFiles()/PurgeObsoleteFiles() never
2816 // deletes any OPTIONS file that has number bigger than any of the file number
2817 // in min_options_file_numbers_.
2818 std::list<uint64_t> min_options_file_numbers_;
2819
2820 // flush_queue_ and compaction_queue_ hold column families that we need to
2821 // flush and compact, respectively.
2822 // A column family is inserted into flush_queue_ when it satisfies condition
2823 // cfd->imm()->IsFlushPending()
2824 // A column family is inserted into compaction_queue_ when it satisfied
2825 // condition cfd->NeedsCompaction()
2826 // Column families in this list are all Ref()-erenced
2827 // TODO(icanadi) Provide some kind of ReferencedColumnFamily class that will
2828 // do RAII on ColumnFamilyData
2829 // Column families are in this queue when they need to be flushed or
2830 // compacted. Consumers of these queues are flush and compaction threads. When
2831 // column family is put on this queue, we increase unscheduled_flushes_ and
2832 // unscheduled_compactions_. When these variables are bigger than zero, that
2833 // means we need to schedule background threads for flush and compaction.
2834 // Once the background threads are scheduled, we decrease unscheduled_flushes_
2835 // and unscheduled_compactions_. That way we keep track of number of
2836 // compaction and flush threads we need to schedule. This scheduling is done
2837 // in MaybeScheduleFlushOrCompaction()
2838 // invariant(column family present in flush_queue_ <==>
2839 // ColumnFamilyData::pending_flush_ == true)
2840 std::deque<FlushRequest> flush_queue_;
2841 // invariant(column family present in compaction_queue_ <==>
2842 // ColumnFamilyData::pending_compaction_ == true)
2843 std::deque<ColumnFamilyData*> compaction_queue_;
2844

2849 // JobContext. Current implementation tracks table and blob files only.
2850 std::unordered_set<uint64_t> files_grabbed_for_purge_;

2852 // A queue to store log writers to close. Protected by db mutex_.

2855 std::deque<SuperVersion*> superversions_to_free_queue_;

2957 // Scheduler to run DumpStats(), PersistStats(), and FlushInfoLog().
2958 // Currently, internally it has a global timer instance for running the tasks.
2959 PeriodicTaskScheduler periodic_task_scheduler_;
2960
2961 // It contains the implementations for each periodic task.
2962 std::map<PeriodicTaskType, const PeriodicTaskFunc> periodic_task_functions_;
2963
2964 // When set, we use a separate queue for writes that don't write to memtable.
2965 // In 2PC these are the writes at Prepare phase.
2966 const bool two_write_queues_;
2967 const bool manual_wal_flush_;
2968
2969 // LastSequence also indicates last published sequence visibile to the
2970 // readers. Otherwise LastPublishedSequence should be used.
2971 const bool last_seq_same_as_publish_seq_;
2972 // It indicates that a customized gc algorithm must be used for
2973 // flush/compaction and if it is not provided vis SnapshotChecker, we should
2974 // disable gc to be safe.
2975 const bool use_custom_gc_;
2976 // Flag to indicate that the DB instance shutdown has been initiated. This
2977 // different from shutting_down_ atomic in that it is set at the beginning
2978 // of shutdown sequence, specifically in order to prevent any background
2979 // error recovery from going on in parallel. The latter, shutting_down_,
2980 // is set a little later during the shutdown after scheduling memtable
2981 // flushes
2982 std::atomic<bool> shutdown_initiated_;
2983 // Flag to indicate whether sst_file_manager object was allocated in
2984 // DB::Open() or passed to us
2985 bool own_sfm_;
2986
2987 // Flag to check whether Close() has been called on this DB
2988 bool closed_;
2989 // save the closing status, for re-calling the close()
2990 Status closing_status_;
2991 // mutex for DB::Close()
2992 InstrumentedMutex closing_mutex_;
2993
2994 // Conditional variable to coordinate installation of atomic flush results.
2995 // With atomic flush, each bg thread installs the result of flushing multiple
2996 // column families, and different threads can flush different column
2997 // families. It's difficult to rely on one thread to perform batch
2998 // installation for all threads. This is different from the non-atomic flush
2999 // case.
3000 // atomic_flush_install_cv_ makes sure that threads install atomic flush
3001 // results sequentially. Flush results of memtables with lower IDs get
3002 // installed to MANIFEST first.
3003 InstrumentedCondVar atomic_flush_install_cv_;
3004
3005 bool wal_in_db_path_;
3006 std::atomic<uint64_t> max_total_wal_size_;
3007
3008 BlobFileCompletionCallback blob_callback_;
3009
3010 // Pointer to WriteBufferManager stalling interface.
3011 std::unique_ptr<StallInterface> wbm_stall_;
3012
3013 // seqno_to_time_mapping_ stores the sequence number to time mapping, it's not
3014 // thread safe, both read and write need db mutex hold.
3015 SeqnoToTimeMapping seqno_to_time_mapping_;
3016
3017 // Stop write token that is acquired when first LockWAL() is called.
3018 // Destroyed when last UnlockWAL() is called. Controlled by DB mutex.
3019 // See lock_wal_count_
3020 std::unique_ptr<WriteControllerToken> lock_wal_write_token_;
3021
3022 // The number of LockWAL called without matching UnlockWAL call.
3023 // See also lock_wal_write_token_
3024 uint32_t lock_wal_count_;
3025};

3094// Fix user-supplied options to be reasonable
3095template <class T, class V>
3096static void ClipToRange(T* ptr, V minvalue, V maxvalue) {
3097 if (static_cast<V>(*ptr) > maxvalue) *ptr = maxvalue;
3098 if (static_cast<V>(*ptr) < minvalue) *ptr = minvalue;
3099}
3100
3101inline Status DBImpl::FailIfCfHasTs(
3102 const ColumnFamilyHandle* column_family) const {
3103 if (!column_family) {
3104 return Status::InvalidArgument("column family handle cannot be null");
3105 }
3106 assert(column_family);
3107 const Comparator* const ucmp = column_family->GetComparator();
3108 assert(ucmp);
3109 if (ucmp->timestamp_size() > 0) {
3110 std::ostringstream oss;
3111 oss << "cannot call this method on column family "
3112 << column_family->GetName() << " that enables timestamp";
3113 return Status::InvalidArgument(oss.str());
3114 }
3115 return Status::OK();
3116}
3117
3118inline Status DBImpl::FailIfTsMismatchCf(ColumnFamilyHandle* column_family,
3119 const Slice& ts) const {
3120 if (!column_family) {
3121 return Status::InvalidArgument("column family handle cannot be null");
3122 }
3123 assert(column_family);
3124 const Comparator* const ucmp = column_family->GetComparator();
3125 assert(ucmp);
3126 if (0 == ucmp->timestamp_size()) {
3127 std::stringstream oss;
3128 oss << "cannot call this method on column family "
3129 << column_family->GetName() << " that does not enable timestamp";
3130 return Status::InvalidArgument(oss.str());
3131 }
3132 const size_t ts_sz = ts.size();
3133 if (ts_sz != ucmp->timestamp_size()) {
3134 std::stringstream oss;
3135 oss << "Timestamp sizes mismatch: expect " << ucmp->timestamp_size() << ", "
3136 << ts_sz << " given";
3137 return Status::InvalidArgument(oss.str());
3138 }
3139 return Status::OK();
3140}
3141
3142inline Status DBImpl::FailIfReadCollapsedHistory(const ColumnFamilyData* cfd,
3143 const SuperVersion* sv,
3144 const Slice& ts) const {
3145 // Reaching to this point means the timestamp size matching sanity check in
3146 // `DBImpl::FailIfTsMismatchCf` already passed. So we skip that and assume
3147 // column family has the same user-defined timestamp format as `ts`.
3148 const Comparator* const ucmp = cfd->user_comparator();
3149 assert(ucmp);
3150 const std::string& full_history_ts_low = sv->full_history_ts_low;
3151 assert(full_history_ts_low.empty() ||
3152 full_history_ts_low.size() == ts.size());
3153 if (!full_history_ts_low.empty() &&
3154 ucmp->CompareTimestamp(ts, full_history_ts_low) < 0) {
3155 std::stringstream oss;
3156 oss << "Read timestamp: " << ucmp->TimestampToString(ts)
3157 << " is smaller than full_history_ts_low: "
3158 << ucmp->TimestampToString(full_history_ts_low) << std::endl;
3159 return Status::InvalidArgument(oss.str());
3160 }
3161 return Status::OK();
3162}
